Award.AwardTitle: L- functions, Galois representations and their arithmetic
Award.AbstractNarration:
The earlier and present work of the principal investigator (PI) has been and continues to be influential upon researchers world-wide.
His work produced many new results on the following three topics:

(a) Galois deformation rings = Hecke algebras (the "R=T" theorems);
(b) p-adic analytic families of automorphic forms and their L-functions;
(c) analysis of arithmetic invariants of p-adic L-functions.

The PI's work has proven intellectual merit. The study of classical and p-adic modular forms has seen explosive development since the 1995 proof by Wiles and Taylor of cases of the Shimura-Taniyama Conjecture (via (a)), and hence, by a celebrated 1986 work of Ribet, Fermat's Last Theorem.

Consequent developments (by the collaboration of many number theorists) include the complete proof of the above conjecture in all cases in 1998, the proof of the Local Langlands Conjecture for GL(N) in 1999, the proof of most instances of the icosahedral case of the Artin Conjecture, and the extension in numerous works of the p-adic theory of Wiles and Taylor from GL(2) to other reductive groups, especially to unitary groups. Despite this great and rapid development, several key results seemed quite out of reach, notably the Serre Modularity Conjecture (1986), the Fontaine-Mazur Conjecture (1990), and the Sato-Tate Conjecture (1965).
It was therefore all the more surprising when in 2005--2006 all three of these conjectures were proven. All these works are directly related to the works of Hida/Tilouine and have good component under the influence of the PI's (present/past) work.
The PI and his collaborator J. Tilouine will continue to work out new problems in these three areas of research, and their research influence upon younger generation will continue to be strong.

The proposed work has had and will have broader impacts.
The invited talks in the number theory section at ICM (Madrid in 2006) were dominantly on these topics; for example, Fujiwara described his results on (a); Skinner-Urban described their results on (b) and Vatsal touched on the topic (c). In their reports in the ICM proceedings, the PI's contribution/impact is well documented.
Since the PI's five research/text books written in the past has had good audience and strong impact on the development of the theory, he plans to write two new books describing the topics in the items (b) and (c) so that graduate students and researchers will have good access to these cutting-edge and fast-developing research topics.

The goal of the research under this plan is the development of an arithmetic theory of automorphic forms on Shimura varieties and their $L$-functions and Galois representations.
Here is a list of the projects as a summary of the program:

I. p-Adic automorphic measure; II. Iwasawa's mu-invariant; III. Non-vanishing modulo p of L-values; IV. Anticyclotomic main conjectures for CM fields; V. L-invariant of Tate curves; VI. L-invariant of abelian p-adic L-functions; VII. Base-change and L-invariant; VIII. Companion forms and local indecomposability.

POR.DRECONTENT:
There would be two fundamental problems in number theory:
  A.  Find an identity of two or more arithmetic invariants of different nature;
  B.  Prove non-triviality/triviality of important arithmetic invariants.
As an example of Problem A, the "R=T" theorem is the identity of the Galois deformation ring  R (purely arithmetically defined invariant attached to a modulo  p  representation) with the Hecke algebra  T (geometrically defined out of modular forms) which is a key in the proof of Fermat's last theorem by A. Wiles (and Hida's theory is essentially used in the proof of Wiles).  Hida and his collaborators made a systematic theory to attack Problem B.  For example, Hida and Tilouine (the collaborator supported as a senior personnel by the grant) invented a technique to measure the size of the image of modular Galois representation with coefficients in a big Hecke algebra (a nontriviality question of the image).   As another example,  the PI sucessfully studied non-vanishing modulo  p  of p-adic L-functions and critical values of L-functions and non-vanishing of L-invariant (of Mazur-Tate-Teitelbaum).  The non-triviality of L-values and p-adic L-function modulo  p  found a strong application in the study of Iwasawa main conjecture for CM fields and resulted the proof by Hida of the anticyclotomic CM main conjecture and by M.-L. Hsieh of the full CM main conjecture.

Intellectual merit.
In many front of research, research of Hida and Tilouine in the past 7 years has contributed well to the good understanding of arithmetic invariants.  These results of Hida has had good influence upon research on non-triviality problems of arithmetic invariants.  Here is a list of notable progresses realized by other researchers under the influence of the work of Hida:
1. A part of the conjecture (and a factorization formula) Hida made in his investigation of L-invariant has been now proven by Harron--Jorza under some assumptions (and hence nonvanishing results obtained by Hida for 3-dimensonal adjoint Galoius representation are generalized to symmetric power of higher dimension.
2. The q-expansion principle obtained by Hida for his study of non-vanishing modulo p of p-adic L-functions is a key to the construction of p-adic L-functions associated to more bigger groups (for example, for the group of  n by n matrices) by Harris-Li-Skinner-Eischen.
3. Madapusi Pera at Harvard has announced that the PI's method of proving irreducibility of Igusa tower for Shimura varieties of abelian type
in a Luminy conference in July 2014.  Hida treated the special cases of Shimura variety of PEL type (which is the base theory for proving the q-expansion principle).
4. Now M.-L. Hsieh has proven substantial cases of the full CM main conjecture reducing it to the proof by Hida of the anti-cyclotomic main conjecture (of less number of variable).

Broader Impact.  In a more broader perspective, in 2005--2012, we have seen big progress: solution of the Serre Modularity Conjecture (by Khare-Wintenberger),  the Fontaine-Mazur Conjecture (Kisin and Emerton), the Sato-Tate Conjecture (by R. Tyalor and his collaborators) and many cases of p-adic Birch-Swinnerton Dyer conjecture (by Skinner and Urban).
All these works are directly and indirectly related to the works of Hida and Tilouine and have some components under the influence of their work.
